issueDTO.title: Default Values and Configuration for limits_config in Alloy Missing After Conversion from Promtail
issueDTO.description:
### What's wrong?

I am migrating from Promtail to Grafana Alloy, and I encountered an issue where limits_config settings are not carried over when using the alloy convert command.


### Steps to reproduce

1. In Promtail, I have the following limits_config settings:

```yaml
limits_config:
  max_line_size: 1000kb
  max_line_size_truncate: true
  readline_rate_enabled: true
  readline_rate: 2500
  readline_burst: 2500
```

2. I ran the conversion command:
`alloy convert --source-format=promtail --output=<OUTPUT_CONFIG_PATH> <INPUT_CONFIG_PATH>
`
3. However, the converted Alloy config did not include the limits_config part.


**Questions!**
1) What are the default values for the following fields in Alloy?

```
type Config struct {
	ReadlineRate        float64          `mapstructure:"readline_rate" yaml:"readline_rate" json:"readline_rate"`
	ReadlineBurst       int              `mapstructure:"readline_burst" yaml:"readline_burst" json:"readline_burst"`
	ReadlineRateEnabled bool             `mapstructure:"readline_rate_enabled,omitempty" yaml:"readline_rate_enabled,omitempty"  json:"readline_rate_enabled"`
	ReadlineRateDrop    bool             `mapstructure:"readline_rate_drop,omitempty" yaml:"readline_rate_drop,omitempty"  json:"readline_rate_drop"`
	MaxStreams          int              `mapstructure:"max_streams" yaml:"max_streams" json:"max_streams"`
	MaxLineSize         flagext.ByteSize `mapstructure:"max_line_size" yaml:"max_line_size" json:"max_line_size"`
	MaxLineSizeTruncate bool             `mapstructure:"max_line_size_truncate" yaml:"max_line_size_truncate" json:"max_line_size_truncate"`
}

```
2) How can I configure these settings in the Alloy configuration file? I am deploying Alloy via Helm charts
3) Should the conversion tool (alloy convert) include the limits_config section automatically, or is this expected behavior?
comments:
This issue has not had any activity in the past 30 days, so the `needs-attention` label has been added to it.
If the opened issue is a bug, check to see if a newer release fixed your issue. If it is no longer relevant, please feel free to close this issue.
The `needs-attention` label signals to maintainers that something has fallen through the cracks. No action is needed by you; your issue will be kept open and you do not have to respond to this comment. The label will be removed the next time this job runs if there is new activity.
Thank you for your contributions!

I was looking in to this from another source, I see that those limits are not configurable but they certainly should be! I wouldn't categorize it as a bug, but I understand why you would consider it that. We'll see if we can get this prioritized soon, otherwise an interested community member is welcome to take it up.
Can I check this issue as well?

Hello, I've been looking into this issue and wanted to share a summary of my findings.

First, my investigation confirms that the `alloy convert` command fails with an error when a Promtail config contains `limits_config`, which seems to be the intended behaviour. 
```
Error: (Error) limits_config is not yet supported in Alloy
```
This happens because the [`validateTopLevelConfig`](https://github.com/grafana/alloy/blob/main/internal/converter/internal/promtailconvert/validate.go#L11) function is called early in the conversion process and explicitly checks for this unsupported block. This validation is triggered for both direct Promtail conversions and for static Grafana Agent conversions.

The code comment for this check references an older, related issue ([#4342](https://github.com/grafana/agent/issues/4342) in the Grafana Agent repository) which discusses potential solutions. One idea was to use the `loki.process` component's [`stage.limit`](https://grafana.com/docs/alloy/latest/reference/components/loki/loki.process/#stagelimit) block. However, this approach seems incomplete for a few key reasons:

*   The `stage.limit` only covers rate-limiting and doesn't support size-based limits like `max_line_size`.
*   More importantly, these limits are most effective when applied as log lines are first read from the source. Applying them later in a `loki.process` stage occurs after the data is already in memory, which is too late to prevent the alloy itself from being impacted by very large log lines.

This suggests that the best place to implement size-based limits (`max_line_size`, `max_line_size_truncate`) is within the `loki.source.*` components themselves.

I was wondering if a hybrid approach would be worth considering. We could:
1.  Add support for the size-based limits directly to the various `loki.source.*` components.
2.  For the rate-limiting settings (`readline_rate`, etc.), guide users to the existing `stage.limit` block within `loki.process`, [which already provides this functionality](https://grafana.com/docs/alloy/latest/reference/components/loki/loki.process/#stagelimit).

This could allow us to reuse the existing `stage.limit` implementation while addressing the missing functionality at the correct architectural layer. I would appreciate any thoughts or guidance on this approach.

issueDTO.title: Support optional object type attributes in Nomad HCL variables
issueDTO.description:
### Proposal

Support `optional(...)` in object type attributes, similar to the [equivalent feature from Terraform](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/expressions/type-constraints#optional-object-type-attributes)

### Use-cases

Variables that use complex types (e.g. `list(object({ ... }))`, where some fields are optional, currently have to be specified in full, or have to be defined as maps where the burden of type validation falls on the template author.

### Attempted Solutions

* Using a `type = map(string)` and checking each field for existence/type-correctness
* Using a `type = string`, setting the value to some structured data format, like JSON or YAML, which is then `(yaml|json)decode`d and its contents' fields checked for existence/type-correctness
comments: Hi @atavakoliyext and thanks for raising this issue. I think supporting the `type` definition within job specification variables in a similar manner to Terraform makes sense. I'll move this onto our roadmapping list.
Great to hear, thank you! I look forward to seeing where it lands on your roadmap 🙂
This seems like a good improvement, always thought this was actually supported. @jrasell I would love to take a crack at it.

issueDTO.title: Up Next queue does not persist order
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
When Anytime is killed and reloaded, the Up Next queue is restored but the order is random. The order of the queue is not persisted to disk.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Add a few episodes to the queue.
2. Force stop Anytime.
3. Restart Anytime.
4. Open the Up Next queue - there order may have changed.

**Expected behavior**
The order of episodes should be persisted between sessions.

**Additional context**
The Queue class is missing an order field. This needs adding, persisting to disk and used to order the queue when re-reading from disk.

issueDTO.title: Using constants in translations
issueDTO.description:
Just started integrating this into our project, and it's fitting much of our use criteria except one key issue around our company / brand name.

We've just had to reword the name of our company from "Company Name" to "Other Detail: Company Name" in our app because of reasons out of our control.  This means we've had to change every area that had "Company Name" in.

What would be amazing would be some way to "refer back" to another translation's entry.

As in, in your app's dictionary ,

```
import { type DeclarationContent } from "intlayer"

const appContent = {
  key: "app",

  content: {
    brandName: "Other Detail: Company Name",
    brandNameShort: "Company Name",
  }
} satisfies DeclarationContent

export default appContent
```

And then, in another page/component, you can pull that in,
```
import { DeclarationContent } from "intlayer"

const overviewContent = {
  key: "overview",
  content: {
    header: "Do all this awesome stuff with %%{app.brandName}%%",
    subHeader: "With %%{app.brandNameShort}%%, you'll be even more awesomer!"
  }
} satisfies DeclarationContent

export default overviewContent
```

Make sense?

Also, just checking on the status of the online editor?  I tried setting up there but ran into a number of hangs and errors, and can't create an organisation, or new project at all.
comments:
I don't love option one because if `brandName` comes first in one language, we'd need to have an empty entry first, then `brandName`, then the second entry.  I think I'll probably go with option 2 until I get the visual editor working fully right at least, but i18n's nesting does look the most ideal solution (but also definitely the most complex one too, unfortunately).

One way or another, thanks so much for the comprehensive response, and, overall your work on this, it's massively appreciated.

Hi @seaders !

Just to communicate the release of [nesting](https://intlayer.org/doc/concept/content/nesting) feature sice the v5! 

I hope it will match your needs

issueDTO.title: Handle Reward Distribution for Completed Challenges
issueDTO.description:
Implement a standalone RewardModule that handles reward distribution to users who complete specific challenges. The module will manage reward records, track claims, and expose an API to handle reward claims securely.

---

### ✅ Tasks

* Create `Reward` entity to define available rewards (e.g., reward type, metadata, challengeId, etc.)
* Create `RewardClaim` entity to record user claims (e.g., userId, rewardId, claimDate)
* Implement service logic to:

  * Check if the user has already claimed a reward for a given challenge
  * Prevent duplicate claims
  * Handle new reward claims
* Create `POST /rewards/claim` endpoint to:

  * Accept reward claim requests with userId and challengeId
  * Validate eligibility
  * Return appropriate success/error response

---

### 🎯 Acceptance Criteria

* The `Reward` and `RewardClaim` entities must be properly defined and persisted in the database
* Users can claim a reward only once per eligible challenge
* Attempting to claim a reward twice for the same challenge must return an error message like: `Reward already claimed`
* The `POST /rewards/claim` endpoint must be functional, documented, and independently testable
* No dependency on other modules; everything required must be self-contained within this module
comments: I am a software developer with experience building reward systems and API development. I can implement secure reward distribution logic, prevent duplicate claims, and create robust database entities with proper validation and error handling.

issueDTO.title: 关于极简模式的设想
issueDTO.description:
首先感谢 @dreamhunter2333 贡献！这里提及一个设想。

现在的功能逐渐丰富，慢慢朝向邮件平台发展，`临时`概念有点弱化。
在使用过的临时邮箱中，界面功能似乎都非常简洁

如：https://www.linshi-email.com/
![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/44989283/a0b4978c-5a96-4edf-b74e-a03a5c6e1b92)

如：https://internxt.com/zh/temporary-email
![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/44989283/c2322faa-bf47-4a2a-a4d3-b916caf05c8d)

如：http://24mail.chacuo.net/
![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/44989283/87f8fc75-cc34-4cac-a901-7281c347e56d)

如：https://rootsh.com/
![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/44989283/155e1e01-5705-4144-bcac-74c616629780)

-----------------------------------

以我常用的 linshi-email.com 为例子（adblock禁用了广告），核心的功能：
- 申请随机邮箱
- 设置自定义邮箱
- 复制邮箱
- 定时自动刷新邮件
- 手动刷新接收邮件

现在项目是满足这些功能的，只是做了一些安全性的限制，例如token登录，登出等。
在我的使用过程中，常常因更换邮箱觉得这些步骤感到繁琐

不清楚owner是如何思考这个问题的。可否出一个类似的模式，更简洁更核心？
comments:
目前通过用户登录做了个切换邮箱的功能，后续可以增加一个不登录的本地存储多个账号的切换模式
![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/32295532/0714b764-a2a1-4af1-a1f3-c20fd17ea908)

不情我还是一起探讨几句。

楼主的想法和问题都很好，这几乎是多数开源项目面临的问题，之前我也有过类似的想法，也提过一些，但最终思考的结果是：

**只能是自己动手了。**

因为开源项目，多数都只能做的是技术，很少能直接做成产品的，原因很简单，萝卜青菜，各有所爱，每个项目在使用起来，对应的应用场景不同，侧重点不同，导致需求都有区别，很多开源项目做着做着，随着不同应用场景下需求越提越多，功能迭代得越复杂，越趋向于大而全。

这项目我自己一路用过来，其实已经能兼容绝大多数应用场景了，个人，团队，甚至于开放站点，得益于其全面的功能，自己做点简单的修改就能很好应用了。

因而，楼主的这个想法实现了，出了个精简版的，马上可能又有要提个Issue加个功能，甚至做个什么团队版的，什么XXX版的，个人感觉真心没必要，因为代码是开源的，需要的话，只能自己改了。本来一套代码就能改出一百个产品，但是基于一百个产品需求去写100套代码真心不现实。

所以，**作者如果能一直维护更新就已经很幸运了**，我们指望作者去直接给我们写一个产品开源出来，感觉有点难为了，因为类似的需求只会越来越多，要么和一些开源项目一样，付费商用定制开发了。

另一方面就是，只要代码稳定，功能多不太可怕，自己还能精简，就怕是功能不全的，要自己补。 像我们这种没什么代码能力的，那才是最可怕的。

我也是完全不熟TS的，也在慢慢一点点折腾，算是一点小乐趣吧，这也不是正是很多人在聚在这的原因（之一）吗？


共勉。

> 目前通过用户登录做了个切换邮箱的功能，后续可以增加一个不登录的本地存储多个账号的切换模式
> ![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/32295532/0714b764-a2a1-4af1-a1f3-c20fd17ea908)

此处切换包含创建，例如 telegram 小程序里面的这种界面
![image](https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/assets/32295532/285326d7-ae7d-4614-86d3-63981a5492f8)

https://github.com/dreamhunter2333/cloudflare_temp_email/releases/tag/v0.5.0
- 增加了本地缓存多地址的功能

感谢开发者的长久支持，项目发展越来越好，功能也越来越多，也变得更好用了。

或许就像楼上 @pdhapy 所言，对于一些特殊的爱好，**只能是自己动手了**

关于极简模式，或许我只是想找一些功能极其简单，界面好看，又能支持自建部署的开源项目（白嫖=_=）

最近有找到相对符合的：
https://ggg.ga
https://email-once.com
https://tempmail100.com

> 感谢开发者的长久支持，项目发展越来越好，功能也越来越多，也变得更好用了。
> 
> 或许就像楼上 @pdhapy 所言，对于一些特殊的爱好，**只能是自己动手了**
> 
> 关于极简模式，或许我只是想找一些功能极其简单，界面好看，又能支持自建部署的开源项目（白嫖=_=）
> 
> 最近有找到相对符合的： https://ggg.ga https://email-once.com https://tempmail100.com

赞，我看看能不能用 AI 生成个极简模式

在 `主页` -> `外观`, 加入了 `使用极简主页`
可以访问 demo 站看看

issueDTO.title: Body is deleted when sending Request
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
The request body is being deleted when sending a request while not being in the body tab.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open a request
2. Write something in the body
3. Send request and see that body does **not** disappear
4. Change to another tab (e.g. headers)
5. Send request
6. Change to body tab and see that body is gone

**Expected behavior**
It should not matter which tab is open while sending a request. Body should not disappear.

**Screenshots/Video**


**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: macOS
 - Version v0.1.0

**Additional context**
It's possibly due to the request body not being rendered. I think that the request body content is read before sending the request. If the editor is not mound however, there is no body content to send --> empty request body. Should be fixable if we do only save the request body when the body tab is actually currently open.
comments: Hi! @SoulKa should I try this too?
Sure :)

issueDTO.title: ig image export/import: Handle signature too
issueDTO.description:
Currently the `ig image export` and `import` commands only care about the image itself, they completely ignore the signature. When a user wants to run an image created with the `import` command the following two things could happen: (1) the signature has to be pulled from the internet when the gadget is run or (2) `verify-image=false` has to be used.

In order to allow users to verify the images, the export and import command should take care of the signature too.

### Implementation Options

#4526 introduced logic to cache the signature on disk, the export command could take the signature from there and the import command could save it there as well.

Ref https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/pull/4526#pullrequestreview-2880931939
Reported by @burak-ok
comments: Can I be assigned this issue? Thanks!!

@mauriciovasquezbernal I am a bit confused about the implementation. The [LoadSigningInformation](https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/bf48127d4a32574e2ef2ba6227c4aae388532987/pkg/oci/oci.go#L830`) function takes `repo` as a parameter but finally uses `defaultOciStore` for the path, which I do not understand. If I follow your intended logic should I access every images separate repository using the same `&imgOpts.AuthOptions` as used in [verifyImage](https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/bf48127d4a32574e2ef2ba6227c4aae388532987/pkg/oci/oci.go#L879) while doing an image `export` or `import`? If you didn't understand previous lines, what I mean to say (in summary) is that I don't which store to use to access the signature and payload info within the `export/import` function.

> The [LoadSigningInformation](https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/bf48127d4a32574e2ef2ba6227c4aae388532987/pkg/oci/oci.go#L830%60) function takes repo as a parameter but finally uses defaultOciStore for the path, which I do not understand

That function shouldn't take the repo, that's a mistake, in fact that parameter is never used, so feel free to fix it while implementing this feature.

When doing export, `loadSigningInformation` should be called to get the local store signature and somehow append that to the generated tarball. Import should do the opposite, take the signature from the tarball and store it locally by using `cacheSigningInformation`.

But now I got a doubt kind of related to this feature: if a user wants to build and export a gadget image with its signature, they'd have to push it to a container registry since cosign isn't able to sign local images. Should we extend the build command with a --sign flag or implement a sign command on ig to be able to sign local images? Thoughts @eiffel-fl, @blanquicet.

> Should we extend the build command with a --sign flag or implement a sign command on ig to be able to sign local images? 
>
Yes, we must support the following **offline**: build + sign + export (image + signature). I'm fine with either option as far as they meet previous use case. I let the implementation details to our experts: @eiffel-fl 🙂.

However, I think this discussion can be separated into to sub-tasks:

1. The `export` and `import` command taking care of the signature:
    - This task is independent if we push the signature to a registry or do it locally (Task 2). Of course, in this former case, users will need to run `pull` to download the signature so that it can be included in the exporting.
    - This is the feature should be included in v0.42.0 as it is preventing users from using exported images in an environment without internet connection.
2. Support signing locally (offline):
    - This can be addressed in a follow-up PR as it mainly improves UX but is not blocking users.

> > The [LoadSigningInformation](https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/bf48127d4a32574e2ef2ba6227c4aae388532987/pkg/oci/oci.go#L830%60) function takes repo as a parameter but finally uses defaultOciStore for the path, which I do not understand
> 
> That function shouldn't take the repo, that's a mistake, in fact that parameter is never used, so feel free to fix it while implementing this feature.
> 
> When doing export, `loadSigningInformation` should be called to get the local store signature and somehow append that to the generated tarball. Import should do the opposite, take the signature from the tarball and store it locally by using `cacheSigningInformation`.
> 
> But now I got a doubt kind of related to this feature: if a user wants to build and export a gadget image with its signature, they'd have to push it to a container registry since cosign isn't able to sign local images. Should we extend the build command with a --sign flag or implement a sign command on ig to be able to sign local images? Thoughts [@eiffel-fl](https://github.com/eiffel-fl), [@blanquicet](https://github.com/blanquicet).

The whole problem here is that it depends on the underlying tools used to sign the image.
With good old gpg, the signature is appended to the artifact signed, when using -s. So, in this case this is pretty easy to handle exporting/importing.
For cosign, things are really different, as the signature is stored in the OCI repo as .sig, see for example:
https://github.com/orgs/inspektor-gadget/packages/container/gadget%2Ftrace_open/436406752?tag=sha256-e2f7214e6e49dababc7cc3d57db367d0c9d3fd4fc5e8315a381958f0aaf2dadc.sig
So, for exporting, we could download everything needed by the verification process and store it in the .tar, then the import would add, to local filesystem, everything needed by the verification process.

Signing image locally is indeed another problem which should be investigated on its own, as it depends whether this is permitted by cosign.

Agree with Francis. For this issue, let's focus on making the import/export aware of the signature if it's available locally. So, for now, users will need to `run` or `image pull` the gadget so that the signature is there before exporting. 

Do you agree?

Let's continue the discussion about signing locally in https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/issues/4616.

Based on the previous discussion, If I'm understanding correctly what we have to do for now for implementation is :

`pull` the gadget before `exporting` it to a tar file

`load` the signature contents from the `defaultOciStore`, write the contents through a blob to `dstStore` (using a .sig extension) and then tar the whole store while `exporting`

obtain the signature contents from the tar file (search for .sig extension in tags)  and then `cache` the contents to the `defaultOciStore`  while `importing`

> pull the gadget before exporting it to a tar file

This will be done by the user with `ig image pull`, so we don't need to make it part of the `ig image export` command.

> load the signature contents from the defaultOciStore, write the contents through a blob to dstStore (using a .sig extension) and then tar the whole store while exporting

obtain the signature contents from the tar file (search for .sig extension in tags) and then cache the contents to the defaultOciStore while importing

That looks correct. I'm not sure about all the details but I look forward to the implementation to discuss it more.

Should I add the signature and payload contents into the ociStore `dstStore` and then tar it? Rn I'm not finding a good implementation of writing directly to the ociStore so I don't know how to do it.
Or should I directly write the signature contents into the tar file. I'll also have to make changes to the `index.json` file right?

Thanks @AdvH039, indeed it's not super easy to implement. While trying to answer your question, I realized we're handing these signatures on a weird way, so I opened #4626, hopefully it'll be a lot easier to import/export signatures after it. As signatures are also stored as OCI images, I'll think the only required change is to also export signatures on 

https://github.com/inspektor-gadget/inspektor-gadget/blob/d98d6969170d939c0cf521c0701ecd16e45eb722/pkg/oci/oci.go#L351-L361

I'm still not sure what we need to in the import logic.
@AdvH039 I think you can already give it a try basing on #4626.
#4626 is now merged, so we can go on with this PR as we would like to have it as part of next release 🙂
Will do asap!! Thanks!!

Hello

Brave browser is based on the Chromium, so the script "install.sh" that configures Chromium, Chrome and Edge should be slightly adapted in the same way for Brave.

Thus duplicate the chrome manifest maybe and call it "launcher-manifest-brave.json":
```
ArrowDL\web-extension\launcher\unix
launcher-manifest-chrome.json
```
And replace with the ID.


Regards

issueDTO.title: Add a feature to skip a file
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When loading a folder, F3D will try to load all files, even files that are not supported. This is intended because a plugin could provide a reader for any file. However, it also means that folders with unopenable files will pollute F3D. Having a way to specify that a file should NOT be opened at all and not added to the file groups would be very practical

**Describe the solution you'd like**
 - Distinguish between unsupported and invalid files
 - Add a `--skip-unsupported-files` CLI option and add it to the default config
 - Add a test opening a folder containing a file to skip with a config file to skip that file based on the extension

**Additional context**
While this may be a bit confusing, this will be very practical for interactive use of F3D and should be trivial to implement
comments:
I would suggest an option to skip-files-except:.

E.g. `--skip-files-except: ".*(gltf|fbx)"`

I know this can be done from command line but not drag and drop a folder: E.g.

`~/Assets$ f3d gltf/*.gltf fbx/*.fbx`
Hi kedoka from discord. I would like to work on this one.

>

> 
> I know this can be done from command line but not drag and drop a folder: E.g.
> 
> `~/Assets$ f3d gltf/*.gltf fbx/*.fbx`

Interesting idea, however this will likely be done differently.
Unassigned as asked by @AoGao-Kedoka

But I want to clarify where is the issue in the code and is there a utility exists which distinctions between the supported and invalid files?

issueDTO.title: Refresh button in Wikibase preview tab
issueDTO.description: While working in my schema for a wikidata upload, I was working between my rows, Schema, Issues, and Preview tabs. I noticed that as I carried out operations on the grid, my Issues and Preview were not being refreshed/updated as I intuitively expected, so that everything would be up to date as I worked.
comments:
I tried reproducing this on the master branch, on 3.7.6 and on 3.7.7, to no avail. Making changes to the grid or to the facets refresh the schema in those cases. It's weird because I did see @cooperzoe having this exact problem in front of my eyes!

There is one exception to that: changing a single cell will not refresh the schema. To me, that's intentional, because if one makes a lot of manual edits to the grid it might be a bit wasteful to refresh the schema preview every time (that can take quite some time).

But it begs the question: why not provide a manual way to refresh the schema issues and preview? That would at least be useful after such manual edits, and would also provide a workaround in cases where the schema should have been refreshed but was not.

We already have such a button in the facets panel, which serves the same purpose: normally, they get refreshed automatically, but not after manual edits, so in rare cases it is useful to have it.

What do you think @cooperzoe?

I like the idea of having a manual refresh right in the schema issues & preview tabs. 

I don't think it should be a button, I think a small refresh icon in the tabs would be the most intuitive.

Here's a sketch of what it would look like (in the preview tab):
![Screenshot 2024-02-05 at 10 52 29 AM](https://github.com/OpenRefine/OpenRefine/assets/52141007/851382b3-bce5-4aad-b440-18f0921aa463)
I want to do this issue. Can you assign me this @wetneb
Automatically unassigned after 45 days of inactivity.
hi, can you assign me this?

issueDTO.title: Memory manager should not use `.equals` to compare objects
issueDTO.description: The `MemoryManager` is using a `List` which ultimately means that `.equals` is being used to compare values in methods such as `persist`. issueDTO.title: Avoid excessive use of `toarray` in unit tests
issueDTO.description:
Many of our unit tests compute the 2-norm of an error vector and compare it to a given tolerance. To this aim, unfortunately, they often convert a Psydac vector to a NumPy array, which is unnecessarily expensive:
```python
error = a - b
assert np.linalg.norm(error.toarray()) < TOL
```
Instead, the same result can be obtained by using the method `inner` of our `Vector` objects, without any unnecessary memory allocation:
```python
# Define 2-norm of vector using inner
norm2 = lambda v: sqrt(v.inner(v))

error = a - b
assert norm2(error) < TOL
```
comments:
While refactoring the `test_operator_evaluation` function (`/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py`) to remove all `.toarray() `(to better leverage PSYDAC’s native vector/matrix structures and improve efficiency), I noticed that the current computation of the variable `error_est` relies on a full dense inverse via:

```
Bmat = B.toarray()

B_inv_mat = np.linalg.inv(Bmat)
b_inv_arr = np.matrix.flatten(B_inv_mat)
error_est = 2 + n1 * n2 * np.max([np.abs(b_inv_arr[i]) for i in range(len(b_inv_arr))])

```
Since we’re avoiding those dense NumPy operations for performance and memory reasons, I believe this calculation of `error_est` no longer fits well in the new context. Computing the full inverse matrix is computationally expensive and somewhat contradictory to the iterative sparse methods we’re testing.

Could you suggest an alternative approach for `error_est`?
For example, I’m considering replacing it with a simpler, lightweight estimate such as:

`error_est = {some num > 0}* n1 * n2`

This is an error estimate based on the maximum absolute value of the inverse matrix. It could read in fact
```python
error_est = np.linalg.norm(Bmat.flat, np.inf)
```
which is the inf-norm of the vectorized matrix. This does not seem to give a sharp estimate, given that it is multiplied by a small number just below (`tol = 1e-5`). Maybe @jowezarek could shed some light on this?

summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the unit tests to compute the 2-norm of an error vector and compare it to a given tolerance without using unnecessary memory allocation and dense NumPy operations, which are computationally expensive and contradictory to the iterative sparse methods being tested.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by refactoring the `test_operator_evaluation` function to leverage PSYDAC's native vector/matrix structures, avoiding dense NumPy operations, and computing the error estimate using a simpler, lightweight approach. An alternative approach could be replacing the current error estimate with a simpler one, such as `error_est = {some num > 0}* n1 * n2`, or using the inf-norm of the vectorized matrix.

issueDTO.title: Track User Progress in the Game
issueDTO.description:
Implement a standalone ProgressModule to monitor and expose a user's progress throughout the NFT Scavenger Hunt game. This will involve creating a `Progress` entity to persist relevant metrics, logic to calculate and update progress stats, and an endpoint to fetch progress details.

---

#### ✅ Tasks:

* Create `Progress` entity with relevant fields (e.g., `userId`, `completedPuzzles`, `totalPuzzles`, `lastUpdated`)
* Develop service logic to calculate progress dynamically (based on puzzles completed, time taken, or other metrics)
* Implement controller with `GET /users/:id/progress` to return current progress for a given user
* Add validation and error handling (e.g., user not found, progress unavailable)
* Document the endpoint in Swagger/OpenAPI

---

#### 🎯 Acceptance Criteria:

* The `Progress` entity must be created and stored independently from other modules
* The `GET /users/:id/progress` endpoint must return user-specific progress as JSON (e.g., `{ userId, completedPuzzles, totalPuzzles, percentComplete }`)
* Must work without relying on or importing other modules in the application
* All logic should be encapsulated within the `ProgressModule`

issueDTO.title: Add some documentation on how `cover_url` is meant to be used
issueDTO.description: it would be great if there would be some documentation about `MediaMetadata::cover_url`, like what format it should be in, or if there is anything platform specific (and if needed what formats are supported, like recommending jpg?)
comments:
It is very platform specific. As of now, Souvlaki leaves it up to the user to change the URL depending on the platform.

For Linux, we follow the MPRIS specification, which actually doesn't say much cover art apart from what's in [here](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/mpris-spec/metadata/#mpris:arturl). It only says that local files should start with `file://` and that it should be an UTF-8 string, which is enforced by Rust. Maybe you can look in the source code of desktop managers such as GNOME or KDE, since these read the field to display it on their media player controls.

For Windows, we use the _SystemMediaTransportControlsDisplayUpdater_, which has [a thumbnail property](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.media.systemmediatransportcontrolsdisplayupdater.thumbnail?view=winrt-22621#windows-media-systemmediatransportcontrolsdisplayupdater-thumbnail). It accepts multiple formats, but we choose to create it using an URI. If setting an URL starting with `file://`, the file is automatically loaded by souvlaki.

For MacOS, you can look into [these lines](https://github.com/Sinono3/souvlaki/blob/384539fe83e8bf5c966192ba28e9405e3253619b/src/platform/macos/mod.rs#L131-L137) of the implementation. These lines refer to creating an [MPMediaItemArtwork](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/mediaplayer/mpmediaitemartwork) object.

I hope this is of use to you. If you find a good way to put this information in the docs, consider opening a pull request 🙂
Documented in 5b89e4bae455e5aed07e2f57f9d8a5b92e62ecf5

As a FYI and because not much is documented in the respective platforms and at least verified on Linux-MPRIS-dbus-KDE, the format of `data:MIMETYPE;base64,BASE64DATA` seems to work without problems.
And i have not yet seen complaints of it not working in windows, mac or other linux environments.
By the way, [mpv-mpris](https://archlinux.org/packages/extra/x86_64/mpv-mpris/) seems to also use this format on linux.

[termusic souvlaki cover_art setting](https://github.com/tramhao/termusic/blob/4fa58b87f15f5d87f705de2b38998563d28ba480/playback/src/mpris.rs#L73-L91).
[MDN data: URLs - URIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/URI/Reference/Schemes/data)

> As a FYI and because not much is documented in the respective platforms and at least verified on Linux-MPRIS-dbus-KDE, the format of `data:MIMETYPE;base64,BASE64DATA` seems to work without problems. And i have not yet seen complaints of it not working in windows, mac or other linux environments. By the way, mpv seems to also use this format on linux.
> 
> [termusic souvlaki cover_art setting](https://github.com/tramhao/termusic/blob/4fa58b87f15f5d87f705de2b38998563d28ba480/playback/src/mpris.rs#L73-L91). [MDN data: URLs - URIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/URI/Reference/Schemes/data)

Perhaps this is the solution to https://github.com/Sinono3/souvlaki/issues/62 for Linux? That's pretty neat, I've noticed even Google Chrome writes to a temporary file and uses a a `file://` url when using MPRIS.

Wow @hasezoey, that's actually great news. I'll add that to the docs as well, but before I'll test on macOS and Windows.

- [x] Tested on macOS
- [ ] Tested on Windows

issueDTO.title: field tag and method name is not parsed
issueDTO.description:
now field tag and interface method name is not parsed, it can not be obfuscated in many cases ( such as is used in reflection)

reference: https://github.com/goretk/gore/blob/3009b3909f08fa910e5a93d893bb66117f3628f9/type2.go#L149
comments:
Hi, I’m interested in working on this issue as part of exploring the GoReSym project for GSoC 2025. I’m fairly new to reversing Go binaries, but I’ve been reversing C binaries and Windows malware for the past few months and really enjoyed it. This issue looks like a great way to start understanding how Go internals work and to get hands-on with the codebase. Looking forward to digging into it!

— Sumanth

Hey @stevemk14ebr , I’m currently digging into how the struct layout for typelinks and itablinks might have changed in Go 1.24.1. I’m comparing it with Go 1.20 to spot any differences that could explain why type/interface recovery is failing. Any pointers or advice on what parts of the runtime changed or what to focus on would be super helpful!

I'm going to bet the `rtype` (runtime type) structures changed slightly. Generally I check the branches of the upstream Go code and inspect commits to the relevant internal type structures. They name their branches after the release versions so it's not too crazy to identify which files were changed across versions and inspect the individual commits that are relevant.

https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/runtime/type.go is a decent starting point. First thought is probably related to the type changes mentioned in their blog here: https://go.dev/blog/coretypes

Figuring out where GoReSym goes off the rails under a debugger can help to identify which runtime code upstream needs inspected more closely.

Thanks for the guidance! You were spot on—rtype was indeed refactored in Go 1.24 to embed *abi.Type, and many fields like hash, str, and kind are now accessed through that. Structs like interfacetype and functype were also moved to internal/abi. I confirmed the breaking changes—will now update GoReSym to handle the new layout based on Go version. Appreciate the pointers!

Also, I just noticed the GSoC deadline is approaching and wanted to ask if there’s still any chance I could be considered. I’d really love the opportunity to work on this. I’ve been building malware in C/C++ and reversing C binaries for the past few months, and once I saw how tools like Sliver use Go, I realized how much harder Go binaries are to reverse—so this project really aligns with what I want to dive into this summer.

You're welcome, good job finding the specifics out! Request to be considered heard, fine by me. For now keep poking around areas you'd like to work on and we can start submitting PRs whenever you have time and like. Thanks for considering GoReSym!

Thanks a lot for the support and encouragement! 🙏 I just submitted my GSoC application for GoReSym — really excited about the opportunity to keep contributing and help push this project forward. I’ll continue exploring more areas to work on and start submitting PRs soon.

Hey @stevemk14ebr ,

Over the past few weeks, @krishnay13 and I have been working through the codebase, focusing on understanding symtab and pclntab. We’ve documented our exploration of their layout, contents, and how GoReSym interacts and parses both tables.

We also tested the tool on Go versions 1.20 and 1.24, carefully noting and documenting the differences. We’re currently working on creating a PR to address the issue soon.

As a quick reminder — I was previously accepted as a GSoC contributor for GoReSym, and as suggested in our discussions, I’m now contributing as an OSS contributor instead. Really excited to continue collaborating and would appreciate any feedback on our progress!

Thanks!

issueDTO.title: Support verbatim boxes in `from_ir`
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the feature you'd like**
Right now, [verbatim boxes](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/braket/latest/developerguide/braket-openqasm-verbatim-compilation.html) are ignored altogether when translating OpenQASM to `Circuit` objects via the `Circuit.from_ir` method:
```python
from braket.circuits import Circuit

oq = """
OPENQASM 3.0;
#pragma braket verbatim
box {
  h $0;
  cnot $0, $1;
}
"""
Circuit.from_ir(oq)
```
```
T  : │  0  │  1  │
      ┌───┐       
q0 : ─┤ H ├───●───
      └───┘   │   
            ┌─┴─┐ 
q1 : ───────┤ X ├─
            └───┘ 
T  : │  0  │  1  │
```
Verbatim boxes need to be supported for faithful translation of OpenQASM, particularly for programs with both verbatim and non-verbatim components.

**Note:** Implementing this feature will require also expanding the [OpenQASM parsing functionality](https://github.com/amazon-braket/amazon-braket-default-simulator-python/tree/main/src/braket/default_simulator/openqasm) in the default simulator package by adding methods for verbatim box handling to the [interpreter](https://github.com/amazon-braket/amazon-braket-default-simulator-python/blob/main/src/braket/default_simulator/openqasm/interpreter.py) and [program context](https://github.com/amazon-braket/amazon-braket-default-simulator-python/blob/main/src/braket/default_simulator/openqasm/program_context.py).

**How would this feature be used? Please describe.**
As mentioned above, this would allow OpenQASM programs with verbatim boxes to be translated correctly.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Entirely verbatim circuits, can be wrapped manually
```python
verbatim_circuit = Circuit().add_verbatim_box(Circuit.from_ir(openqasm))
```
but this fails for programs with verbatim boxes in between non-verbatim instructions.
comments:
Interested in tackling this. It seems like all the updates for this feature needs to be done at this default simulator repo `openqasm_parser.py`? 
https://github.com/amazon-braket/amazon-braket-default-simulator-python/blob/main/src/braket/default_simulator/openqasm/parser/openqasm_parser.py#L71

The parser already supports [`box` statements](https://github.com/amazon-braket/amazon-braket-default-simulator-python/blob/9edb1d27336e036bacc509377107b99f74e26a37/src/braket/default_simulator/openqasm/parser/openqasm_parser.py#L250-L255). The changes should be made one level up, in the `openqasm` directory (there should be no need to modify anything in the `parser` subdirectory.

There is a `Box` class as well as a `visitBoxStatement()` method in `openqasm_parser.py`. I noticed that in order to wrap the circuit properly, we would need to implement `VerbatimBoxStart` and `VerbatimBoxEnd` classes. They do not exist in the amazon-braket-simulator-python repo. 
Please correct me if I am wrong @speller26 , wouldn't we need an internal `Instruction` class to call something like `Instruction(VerbatimBoxStart(), target=[])`? I don't believe such a class exists in the codebase either.  
Are we allowed to implement such a class or is it not necessary?

The actual implementation of the box is up to the subclass; as long as there's some abstract method to enclose a block of instructions inside a box while keeping the context that the box belongs to a `verbatim` pragma, it'll be possible to support verbatim boxes.

The `BeginVerbatimBox` and `EndVerbatimBox` instructions are a Braket SDK implementation detail; you could totally implement the verbatim box wrapper to insert both instructions in the appropriate place.
Thank you, it makes sense!
Hi @robotastray, - please let me know if you want to continue working on this issue! Happy to review if it'll be ready.

Hello,
I encountered some issues after realising that some of the functions I was importing were causing a circular import error. issueDTO.title: Implement User Authentication using JWT
issueDTO.description:
Here’s an improved and more detailed version of your GitHub issue with expanded **description**, clear **tasks**, and **acceptance 
We need to implement a secure and efficient user authentication system for the application using **JSON Web Tokens (JWT)**. This feature will enable users to **register**, **log in**, and **stay authenticated** across sessions, while ensuring protected routes are accessible only to verified users. This implementation will include both **access tokens** (with expiry) and optional setup for **refresh tokens** (optional in MVP phase).

JWT authentication will be critical for safeguarding user data and controlling access across private endpoints.

---

### **✅ Tasks:**

* [ ] **Create authentication module** (if not already existing)
* [ ] **Set up `/auth/register` route**

  * Accept `name`, `email`, and `password`
  * Hash the password before storing using `bcrypt`
* [ ] **Set up `/auth/login` route**

  * Validate credentials
  * Return a signed JWT access token upon success
* [ ] **Implement `JwtStrategy` using `@nestjs/passport` and `passport-jwt`**
* [ ] **Create `JwtAuthGuard` to protect private routes**
* [ ] **Add token expiration logic**

  * Set access token to expire (e.g. in 15 mins)
  * (Optional) Add refresh token support
* [ ] **Update `User` entity with necessary fields (if missing)**

  * E.g. hashed password, createdAt, updatedAt
* [ ] **Add global exception handling for unauthorized access**

---

### **✅ Acceptance Criteria:**

* [ ] Users can successfully register and have their password hashed securely
* [ ] Users can log in with valid credentials and receive a JWT
* [ ] JWT includes user ID and expires in 15 minutes (or configured time)
* [ ] All private routes protected with `JwtAuthGuard` reject unauthenticated access
* [ ] Authenticated users can access protected endpoints without errors
* [ ] Invalid or expired tokens should result in `401 Unauthorized`
* [ ] Code is clean, modular, and follows NestJS best practices
comments:
I'd like to take on this task. I will:

* Set up the `/auth/register` and `/auth/login` endpoints using NestJS best practices
* Hash passwords securely with `bcrypt` and store them properly in the User entity
* Implement `JwtStrategy` and `JwtAuthGuard` to protect private routes
* Configure JWT access tokens to expire in 15 minutes
* (Optionally) prepare for refresh token support in a future phase
* Add global exception handling for unauthorized requests
* Ensure clean code structure, modular service separation, and full type safety
* Test for edge cases including invalid credentials and token expiry

I’ll make sure the implementation is secure, testable, and production-ready. Please assign me.

My name is Ola, and i'm a skilled backend engineer and I'm super excited to develop a robust jwt auth flow for this project, I am well skilled in nest js and every other tool required to handle this task.

@yusuftomilola  I’d like to propose implementing a secure user authentication system using JWT for our Node.js and Express backend. Since I’m already familiar with Node.js, Express, MongoDB, and JavaScript, I believe I can efficiently set this up to ensure users can register, log in, and access protected routes safely.

Hi there,

I'm Jephthah Yohanna, a backend-focused developer experienced with Node.js, JWT-based authentication, and secure route protection. I’ve worked on similar systems using bcrypt, Passport strategies, and token expiration flows, and I’m comfortable building clean, modular auth logic that fits right into a NestJS architecture.

This is a solid and well-scoped issue. Here's how I’d go about it:

    Set up the authentication module and routes for /auth/register and /auth/login, with proper input validation and password hashing using bcrypt.

    Generate JWT access tokens on successful login and structure them to include the user ID and expiry.

    Implement JwtStrategy using @nestjs/passport and secure private routes with a custom JwtAuthGuard.

    Set token expiration and add optional refresh token handling if needed later.

    Update the User entity with any missing fields and ensure exceptions are handled cleanly across the board.

I’ll make sure the implementation follows NestJS best practices and that all acceptance criteria are met. I’d be happy to jump in and get started as soon as possible.

issueDTO.title: Raise a runtime error if Python sdk parameters are passed wrong
issueDTO.description:
So far I've been relying a lot of python optional type signatures, however they are not mandatory, which means users can send incorrect format like `labels="mylabel"` instead of `labels=["mylabel"]`, this causes it to fail only when reaching the http endpoint which is hard to debug

Instead we should have a warning/background exception for users if they are using the wrong parameters, and bail from sending the message to langwatch

We don't want to have an actual runtime exception breaking users application because we don't want our monitoring to possibly break users applications, but we want to inform them nevertheless
comments:
Hi @rogeriochaves 👋,

Thanks for creating this issue. I’d like to work on it.

Just to confirm the approach before I proceed:

I’ll add runtime validation for key parameters like labels to ensure they are of the correct type (e.g., labels should be a list).

If an incorrect type is detected (e.g., labels="mylabel"), I’ll raise a non-breaking warnings.warn() to alert the user.

In such cases, the SDK will skip sending the event to LangWatch to avoid downstream errors, but the user's application will continue running without interruption.

I’ll also include unit tests to validate this behavior.

Please let me know if this approach aligns with what you had in mind. I’m happy to get started once approved.

Thanks!

Instead, the SDK should have a warning or background exception for users if they are using the wrong parameters.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the Python SDK to raise a runtime error if the parameters are passed in the wrong format, such as passing a string instead of a list for the 'labels' parameter.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by adding runtime validation for key parameters like labels to ensure they are of the correct type (e.g., labels should be a list). If an incorrect type is detected, a non-breaking warnings.warn() should be raised to alert the user, and the SDK should skip sending the event to LangWatch to avoid downstream errors.

issueDTO.title: ✨ Terminal Utility: Tabs & Split View
issueDTO.description: ### Describe the solution you'd like Being able to have more than one shell in a project would be great. **Please note the following behaviors:** - The plus icon adds a new terminal tab (not in a group). - The minus button closes the selected tab. - Press the delete key while terminal tab sidebar is in focus to close the selected tab. - Drag an ungrouped terminal tab on top of another ungrouped terminal tab to create a group. - Drag an ungrouped terminal tab into an existing group to add it to that group. - Drag a terminal tab within a group to reorder it. - Drag a grouped terminal tab to another group to move it to another group. ### Describe alternatives you've considered Here are some examples of how it handles Webstorm: https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/806104/161374050-7e8cc0b5-e731-49a3-a7de-6fd41328adea.mp4 ### Additional context ### Depends on - #350
comments: @Angelk90 I agree that it should open as a drawer like in your video. That video is from VSCode, and demonstrates how it handles terminal tabs and split terminal views. The question we need to answer for this is how are we going to do multiple terminals in this drawer? Will we use tabs? How will we handle split terminals? Will terminals be the only thing that exists in this drawer or will there be other kinds of things like output, issues, debug, console, etc.?

This is the design that we will use for multiple terminals. We need this tab system in place in the status bar and the git controls moved up to the toolbar first, then in the terminal tab build the multiple terminal tabs UI, this is how this would look. **Please note the following behaviors:** - The plus icon adds a new terminal tab (not in a group). - The minus button closes the selected tab. - Press the delete key while terminal tab sidebar is in focus to close the selected tab. - Drag an ungrouped terminal tab on top of another ungrouped terminal tab to create a group. - Drag an ungrouped terminal tab into an existing group to add it to that group. - Drag a terminal tab within a group to reorder it. - Drag a grouped terminal tab to another group to move it to another group. @bombardier200  I am working on the Drag to group functionality. Currently I implemented onDrag and onDrop on the terminal list view and wrote the DropDelagate. Dragging is working, while dropping I can access the terminal being dragged. But I could not access the terminal or group on which dragged terminal is dropped. Do you have any idea on how to get that? here is my link to file where I have added the DropDelegate https://github.com/gokul1099/CodeEdit/blob/terminal-tabs-split-view/CodeEdit/Features/DebugArea/Views/DebugAreaTerminalView.swift
@gokul1099 can you include a video? It will help me see what exactly you are talking about

https://github.com/CodeEditApp/CodeEdit/assets/42144106/d1125933-7c33-4394-a2f6-e4e913be7fd2

In the above video, while dragging I could access the terminal being dragged (third terminal). I want to access the second terminal also(as the dragged terminal is dropped on this), So that I can group both of them.

Hi @austincondiff, I'd like to tackle this!

Here are a few assumptions I'm going with, based on what I've read here so far or what I think. Please correct me if any of them are wrong.

- Groups cannot be nested
- If there's multiple terminals/groups selected, show `CEContentUnavailableView("Multiple Selection")`
- Selecting a group focuses the first terminal in that group
- Selecting a terminal focuses that terminal, unless its in a different group, in which case it switches to that group

Here's an alternative, which is what I was expecting until I saw your design which contradicted with it:

- Selecting a group displays all of its terminals on the right-hand side, the first terminal starts focused
- Selecting a terminal displays only that terminal on the right-hand side

Since names are getting quite long in this area, I have a little rename suggestion.
It would also make sense with the way the folders are laid out.

Here's what I mean:
- `UtilityAreaTerminalView` -> `TerminalUtilityView`
- `UtilityAreaTerminalTab` -> `TerminalUtilityTab`
- `UtilityAreaDebugView` -> `DebugUtilityView`
- `UtilityAreaOutputView` -> `OutputUtilityView`

That way things which relate to the utility area as a whole are prefixed with `UtilityArea` while individual utilities have shorter names.

I'm suggesting this because I'm getting names like 
- `UtilityAreaTerminalSelection` -> `TerminalUtilitySelection`
- `UtilityAreaTerminalGroup` -> `TerminalUtilityGroup`
- `UtilityAreaTerminalTerminalView` -> `TerminalUtilityTerminalView`

I am in favor of those name changes. We still need to figure out a good way to represent the groups. Since the creation of this issue, our utility area has changed quite a bit. If you are able to join our weekly meetup at 3 PM UTC on Discord (15 minutes after the time of posting) we can discuss this as a group.

Okay so I think this is how we should represent groups (I've also updated the issue description with this)... As you can see, when a tab is split, both are under a group. By default the name of the group reflects how many terminals are in the split. The user can later however rename the group to whatever they want.

Ah sorry I hadn't seen your message earlier I would've liked to be at that meeting!

Great for the naming changes, I'll make a separate PR for that later.

The rest seems good, I got terminals side-by-side and grouping with a few small issues left.

I should be able to finish this tomorrow!

Hi @austincondiff, I'm a iOS developer and really like this project and want to help.

I already fork and clone the project and now I'm analyzing the UtililyAreaTerminalSidebar, put the preview to work, leaned how project is working like the ViewModel of the UtilityArea Feature. 

I read the documentation and I think I can start helping.

Could you assign this issue to me?

I already enter the discord server, but not send any message yet. I lost the weekly meeting cuz I'm from Brazil and made a mistake with the time.

Thanks

@SoreGus Assigned it to you. Thank you for your help. You didn't miss our meetup. If you'd like, you can still join in 8.5 hours from the time of posting (3:00 PM UTC).

If you can think of a better way to represent these split groups feel free to do whatever feels best and most intuitive.

summary.otherNotes: This issue is labeled as 'bug-confirmed', 'L-JavaScript', 'A-Linter', and 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. The expected behavior is for the `useJsonImportAttribute` rule to detect `type: json` in another line without throwing an error, even with line breaks. The fix can be implemented by adjusting the rule to handle line breaks correctly.

issueDTO.title: Duplicate Shepherd.js Tour Steps Targeting .swiper
issueDTO.description:
**Description:**
In script.js, there are two tour steps targeting the same .swiper class:
One introduces the template swipe feature
The second introduces the Select button inside the same element
This causes redundancy and potentially overlaps in popups.

**Expected Fix:**
Merge both messages into one
Or separate the steps with unique element selectors (e.g., the actual button)

**Contributor Note:**
I’m a contributor in SSOC 4, and I would like to resolve this UI/UX inconsistency.
@mryashsinghal  Please assign this issue to me.
comments: @chahalsahil , you can work on this issue

summary.main: In script.js, there are two tour steps targeting the same .swiper class, causing redundancy and potentially overlaps in popups. The issue needs to be fixed to introduce the template swipe feature and the Select button inside the same element in a consistent and user-friendly manner.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the tour steps to target unique elements, eliminating redundancy and potential overlaps in popups, and ensuring a consistent user experience.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by merging both tour steps into one or separating the steps with unique element selectors, such as the actual button.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'good first issue' and 'SSOC S4', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle.

We would like a new entry on the term `rfind()` under strings in C++. The entry should be in `content/cpp/concepts/strings/terms/rfind/rfind.md`

- A description of the term
- A ##Syntax section that includes the syntax of the method and its details
- An ##Example section that show an example of the current entry.

issueDTO.title: Implement NFT Contract Core with OpenZeppelin
comments:
Hi Team,

I'd like to contribute to implementing the core NFT token functionality using OpenZeppelin Stellar contracts. I have extensive experience building standard NFT smart contracts  in Rust/Soroban.

In previous projects, I've developed production-grade NFT contracts using OpenZeppelin templates, implemented robust ownership tracking and token storage systems and created comprehensive test suites for core token operations.

I can deliver a fully-tested implementation within 48 hours. 

Let me know if I can proceed!
Can I take this up?

Hey team! 

I'd love to take on this smart contract issue. I'm passionate about writing clean, secure, and efficient on-chain logic that powers great user experiences. With a strong grasp of Starknet development and a growing toolkit around Cairo and Dojo, I'm excited to contribute to the core mechanics of your project.

Kindly assign, sirs 🙏 Looking forward to shipping something solid!

## Issue assigned to: @emarc99  

Welcome aboard. We're glad to have you contributing to **KindFi**, a Web3 crowdfunding platform for real-world impact. This issue is part of our open-source roadmap

---

### Contribution Checklist

To ensure smooth collaboration and maintain consistency across the codebase, please follow these rules:

- [ ] Join our **Telegram community** to stay updated and connect with maintainers and contributors. The link is in the README. Ask here if you need it.
- [ ] Provide an **initial update within 24 hours** of being assigned the issue. Let us know if you're starting or facing any blockers.
- [ ] **Do not fork the repository**. Instead, accept the invitation sent to your email to collaborate directly.
- [ ] **Enable signed commits**. This verifies you are a real contributor. Use [this guide](https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/managing-commit-signature-verification/about-commit-signature-verification) to set it up.
- [ ] For any questions (e.g., local setup, `.env`), ask in the **Telegram channel**.

---

### Technical References

- [KindFi Code Style Guide](https://kindfis-organization.gitbook.io/development/code-and-design-guide-style-and-conventions)
- [How to Contribute](https://kindfis-organization.gitbook.io/development/how-to-contribute)
- [Stellar Smart Contracts](https://developers.stellar.org/docs/smart-contracts)
- [Trustless Work Escrow Docs](https://docs.trustlesswork.com/)

---

If you have any doubts, please ask in the Telegram group. Clear communication is key. When ready, assign the issue to yourself and let's get started.

issueDTO.title: Double Border on <Input /> Component Focus State
issueDTO.description:
**Describe**
Currently, the <Input /> component in Care UI displays a double border when in a focused state. This appears visually inconsistent and could likely be improved to a cleaner single-border focus style.

> [!Note]
It is unclear whether this is an intended design decision or an unintended style issue. Clarification or enhancement may be needed.


To Reproduce
Steps to observe the issue:
	1.	Open any form or screen using the <Input /> component in the Care interface.
	2.	Focus on the input field.
	3.	Observe the border styling.


Screenshots
Double border shown on focus:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cd8fa2ac-6fa7-46ca-9797-0790dbe9332b



🚨 DO NOT EDIT BELOW THIS LINE 🚨

Instructions for Requesting Assignment:

To request assignment, please clearly outline your solution and timeline by commenting on the issue using the format below:

Describe your solution clearly:
Explain how you plan to resolve the issue. For example:
	•	Override default focus styles in Tailwind with focus-visible:outline-none and use a consistent border-* utility.
	•	Audit all usages of <Input /> to ensure consistency.

Expected Timeline:
	•	End date: [Expected PR completion date]

Additional Context:
Include any references, design tokens, or visual specs that might guide the implementation.

🚨 Your assignment may be unassigned if there is no activity or update within the stated timeline unless communicated clearly.
comments:
Hi! Can you please assign this issue to me?

**Approach:** I will disable the focus outline on the inputs to remove the double border effect.  
**ETA:** 24 hours

Thanks!

Hi, I'd like to work on this issue.

**Proposed Solution:**

The double-border appearance seems to result from overlapping border and outline, I will address this issues by

- Disabling the default focus outline
- Applying a consistent single-border focus style
- Auditing similar components to ensure uniformity

**ETA**: June 26, 2025

Hey Team, i would like to work on this issue.
ETA : 1 day
cc: @vinutv

As mentioned earlier, the double-border issue was due to overlapping `outline` and `border` styles on focus. I've made the following changes to address this:

### Change Made:
- Disabled the default browser focus outline by adding `outline-none focus:outline-none`.
- Ensured a consistent border style on focus using `focus-visible:ring-0` and `focus:border-primary-400` (for brand consistency).
- Applied this fix in the `Input`.

ETA: 1 Day

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c8c37456-afca-4e54-b845-09d2e8214f5c

issueDTO.title: Upgrade golangci-lint to v2
issueDTO.description:
golangci-lint has had a major version bump to v2
we should migrate to this new version
there is a migration guide available: https://golangci-lint.run/product/migration-guide/
comments:
Hey @antoninbas - I've been chipping away at this for a week now. Could I get your advice?

So far I've addressed all the staticcheck errors (on this branch https://github.com/petertran-avgo/antrea/commits/7093-bump-golang-ci-lint-v2/ ) which is pretty large.

There are 1157 remaining gosec issues:
* 1113 of them are `G104`: 
> Errors unhandled (gosec)

Which is when a method returns an error but we don't check it. Here's an example:

https://github.com/antrea-io/antrea/blob/main/cmd/antrea-agent/agent.go#L382
```
informer.SetTransform(k8s.NewTrimmer(k8s.TrimPod)) // returns error but we don't check it
return informer
```

Do you think it would be okay to ignore `G104`? I havent looked at the remaining 43 issues but they should be much more manageable than g104

I did the conversion recently for another smaller repository. When I used the conversion tool that golangci-lint provides, it automatically added the `legacy` preset which ignores G104: https://github.com/antrea-io/antrea-ui/blob/main/.golangci.yml#L29

I recommend using the conversion tool, focusing on moving to the v2 configuration, and trying to get to parity with what we have today (or as close as possible). If follow up changes are needed / desired (e.g., to enable more linters or rules, or to be more explicit about which rules are disabled), these changes should be performed in a separate PR IMO.
Are you referring to the `migrate` sub-command?
And thanks for the tip about `legacy`! Down to 36 gosec errors

> Are you referring to the `migrate` sub-command?

Yes. I'd suggest running that first. `legacy` should be added by default, or at least it was in my case.
Thank you! Reflecting on this now, I recall the exclusions list having extra (at the time I thought) "directories" that didn't make sense to me that I removed. `legacy` must have been on there
can we close this issue, as it has been solved in PR #7151, or is there something I can work upon which is remaining?

issueDTO.title: chore(<test>): Increase integration test coverage by not relying only on pipelines based on container components
issueDTO.description:

Most [pipelines that we use for integration tests](https://github.com/kubeflow/pipelines/tree/3c2bd72630245b69922a5955cfca6be2cdee2801/backend/test/v2/resources) are based on container components and have no inputs/outputs.
We could improve the test coverage without increasing the test duration if we just made the pipelines a bit more complex by adding inputs and outputs and at least two tasks.

issueDTO.title: Development console flicker
issueDTO.description:
### The issue

The prompt/widget area of the development console flickers when it re-draws. While on the surface this appears to be purely aesthetic, this flicker makes the console look a bit less stable, which might cause users to worry about missing log messages, which is not fun.

### Possible solutions

The following solutions are not mutually exclusive, and are in the order that it makes sense to apply them in:

- don't update if nothing changed (relatively easy, highest gain)
- compute more before drawing

### Caught in Action
#### Most of the time
![image](https://github.com/HeyPuter/puter/assets/7225168/2407e299-3015-4b15-b246-f6f362d77b67)
#### Briefly, during a re-draw
![image](https://github.com/HeyPuter/puter/assets/7225168/a6fdf9e8-baf7-4426-8892-b2ab71f2734d)

issueDTO.title: Challenge 0 - Better Error Message Handling when failed to download file from IPFS
issueDTO.description:
## Overview

Currently we do not have a good error message handling to indicate metadata download failure on Challenge 0, it will show download successful even though the download failed

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eb96f52a-3238-447d-8656-a5f6eb6de9ee)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cd3793c2-32ca-45bb-a467-4b45ce71e586)

## Acceptance Criteria
- For known errors, we should use `404` for not found, and `400` for incorrect input as HTTP Return codes instead of Error 500, which does not tell us anything about the error.
- The toast should indicate the appropriate error message when an error happens.


## Tips

- Take a look at the NextJS API Routes to update the logic
comments:
I'd like to take this issue.
Hi, I’d like to apply for this issue!

**Plan:** I’ll update the logic in the relevant Next.js API route to return more meaningful HTTP status codes — `404` for missing metadata, `400` for invalid inputs, and reserve `500` for actual server errors. I’ll also ensure the client shows appropriate toast messages based on the specific error response.

**Why me:** I’ve worked extensively with Next.js API routes and understand how to properly structure error handling. Clear, actionable error messages greatly improve UX, and I’ll make sure they’re user-friendly and informative.

Looking forward to improving this experience! ✅
Hi @metalboyrick , 
I couldn't find a contribution guide. Please point me to it.

issueDTO.title: Thermal boundary condition for particles
issueDTO.description:
With a thermal boundary condition, a particle exiting the domain is re-injected with a random direction and thermal velocity. This should be implemented by:
- having a new type of `ParticleBoundary`, like `Absorbing`;
- having a new float input variable `boundary_temperature`, stored in `m_boundary_temperature` [here](https://github.com/Hi-PACE/hipace/blob/development/src/Hipace.H#L323) and `query`ed [here](https://github.com/Hi-PACE/hipace/blob/development/src/Hipace.cpp#L217) (many examples are in the code for these);
- Using this temperature [here](https://github.com/Hi-PACE/hipace/blob/development/src/particles/pusher/GetAndSetPosition.H#L90) to determine the particle's properties.

Notes:
1. The particle's position must be calculated from the actual trajectory or a particle hitting the boundary with v1 and being *reflected* with a different velocity v2.
2. This issue is reserved for someone, please don't self-assign (for once)

summary.main: A thermal boundary condition for particles is needed, where a particle exiting the domain is re-injected with a random direction and thermal velocity. This should be implemented by adding a new type of `ParticleBoundary`, like `Absorbing`, and having a new float input variable `boundary_temperature` stored in `m_boundary_temperature`. The particle's position must be calculated from the actual trajectory or a particle hitting the boundary with v1 and being reflected with a different velocity v2.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for particles exiting the domain to be re-injected with a random direction and thermal velocity, based on the thermal boundary condition. This should be implemented without breaking responsiveness or causing regression on other header elements.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by adding a new type of `ParticleBoundary`, like `Absorbing`, and having a new float input variable `boundary_temperature` stored in `m_boundary_temperature`. This temperature should be used to determine the particle's properties, and the particle's position must be calculated from the actual trajectory or a particle hitting the boundary with v1 and being reflected with a different velocity v2.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with before/after code changes and relevant documentation updates if possible.

issueDTO.title: Missing taint findings, possibly due to `focus-metavariable`
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

I've [raised this on Slack](https://semgrep.slack.com/archives/C018NJRRCJ0/p1713267249139299) and Lewis referred me here, saying that it might be a bug with `focus-metavariable`. 

Refer to [this playground](https://semgrep.dev/playground/s/10lz1) for an example. Source and sink are correctly identified but somehow no match is found. 

Also worth mentioning that this seems to be a regression. My org maintains a set of custom rules along with a test suite and we found out about this bug because the tests started failing after upgrading from 1.64.0 to the latest version. 

**What is the priority of the bug to you?**

- [ ] P0: blocking your adoption of Semgrep or workflow
- [x] P1: important to fix or quite annoying
- [ ] P2: regular bug that should get fixed

**Environment**

Reproducible on playground and locally.
comments:
This example works: https://semgrep.dev/playground/s/d8qdP

Note that all I did was remove the type annotations. Perhaps an IL issue.
hello, i see this issue has been open for a while and root cause already identified but no pr has been submitted, do you guys mind if i submit?

repository.description: Lightweight static analysis for many languages. Find bug variants with patterns that look like source code.
repository.name: semgrep

summary.main: The issue is about missing taint findings, possibly due to `focus-metavariable`, which is affecting the functionality of Semgrep. The issue is reproducible on the playground and locally, and it seems to be a regression that occurred after upgrading from 1.64.0 to the latest version.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for Semgrep to correctly identify and report taint findings, and the issue should be fixed to ensure this functionality is working as intended.
summary.attemptedFixes: The root cause of the issue is identified as `focus-metavariable`, and removing type annotations seems to resolve the issue. A potential fix could involve investigating and addressing any IL issues.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'good first issue', indicating it's a suitable issue for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with a description of the fix and any relevant changes.
